intro: Parnassia parviflora, commonly known as the small-flowered mountain buttercup, is a flowering plant native to alpine and subalpine regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It is characterized by its delicate, white, five-petaled flowers and smooth, waxy leaves that often have a bluish or purplish hue. The plant typically grows in moist, rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in cool, high-altitude environments. Its flowers bloom in early summer, and the plant is often found in meadows and mountainous areas. Parnassia parviflora is a member of the Ranunculaceae family, which includes many other showy, often toxic plants.
